memberdef.argsstring: (const Polygon_2< Kernel, Container > &pgn1, const Polygon_2< Kernel, Container > &pgn2, General_polygon_with_holes_2< Polygon_2< Kernel, Container > > &res)
memberdef.name: join

briefdescription.para: computes the union of two polygons.

parameterdescription.para: the 1st input polygon.
the 2nd input polygon.
the resulting union of pgn1 and pgn2.

simplesect.para: true if the two input polygons overlap.

memberdef.argsstring: (const Polygon_2< Kernel, Container > &pgn1, const Polygon_2< Kernel, Container > &pgn2, General_polygon_with_holes_2< Polygon_2< Kernel, Container > > &res, UsePolylines=Tag_true())
memberdef.name: join

briefdescription.para: computes the union of two polygons.

parameterdescription.para: determines whether the boundaries of pgn1 and pgn2 are treated as cyclic sequences of single ( $x$-monotone) segments or as a cyclic sequences of ( $x$-monotone) polylines. If substituted with CGAL::Tag_true, which is the default, pgn1 and pgn2 are converted into a general polygons bounded by polylines before the operation is actually performed. Then, the resulting general polygons with holes are converted back to standard polygons with holes. If substituted with CGAL::Tag_false, pgn1 and pgn2 are used as is. Refer to Traits Selection for more information.
the 1st input polygon.
the 2nd input polygon.
the resulting union of pgn1 and pgn2.

simplesect.para: true if the two input polygons overlap.

memberdef.argsstring: (const Polygon_2< Kernel, Container > &pgn1, const Polygon_with_holes_2< Kernel, Container > &pgn2, General_polygon_with_holes_2< Polygon_2< Kernel, Container > > &res)

memberdef.name: join

briefdescription.para: Given a range of polygons (respectively general polygons) or a range of polygons with holes (respectively general polygons with holes) computes the union of all polygons in the range and inserts the resulting polygons with holes (respectively general polygons with holes) into a container via an output iterator.

parameterdescription.para: the first iterator of the input range. Its value type is either Polygon_2 (respectively General_polygon_2) or Polygon_with_holes_2 (respectively General_polygon_with_holes_2).
the past-the-end iterator of the input range. Its value type is either Polygon_2 (respectively General_polygon_2) or Polygon_with_holes_2 (respectively General_polygon_with_holes_2).
the output iterator for the result. Its dereference type must be convertible to Polygon_with_holes_2 (respectively General_polygon_with_holes_2).

simplesect.para: the past-the-end iterator of the output container.

memberdef.argsstring: (InputIterator begin, InputIterator end, OutputIterator oi, UsePolylines=Tag_true())
memberdef.name: join

briefdescription.para: Given a range of polygons (respectively general polygons) or a range of polygons with holes (respectively general polygons with holes) computes the union of all polygons in the range and inserts the resulting polygons with holes (respectively general polygons with holes) into a container via an output iterator.

parameterdescription.para: determines whether the boundaries of the polygons in the input range are treated as cyclic sequences of single ( $x$-monotone) segments or as a cyclic sequences of ( $x$-monotone) polylines. If substituted with CGAL::Tag_true, which is the default, the input polygons are converted into general polygon with holes , bounded by polylines before the operation is actually performed. Then, the resulting general polygons with holes are converted back to standard polygons with holes. If substituted with CGAL::Tag_false, pgn1 and pgn2 are used as is. Refer to Traits Selection for more information.
the first iterator of the input range. Its value type is either Polygon_2 (respectively General_polygon_2) or Polygon_with_holes_2 (respectively General_polygon_with_holes_2).
the past-the-end iterator of the input range. Its value type is either Polygon_2 (respectively General_polygon_2) or Polygon_with_holes_2 (respectively General_polygon_with_holes_2).
the output iterator for the result. Its dereference type must be convertible to Polygon_with_holes_2 (respectively General_polygon_with_holes_2).

simplesect.para: the past-the-end iterator of the output container.

memberdef.argsstring: (InputIterator1 begin1, InputIterator1 end1, InputIterator2 begin2, InputIterator2 end2, OutputIterator oi)

parameterdescription.para: the first iterator of the 1st input range. Its value type is Polygon_2 (respectively General_polygon_2).
the past-the-end iterator of the 1st input range. Its value type is Polygon_2 (respectively General_polygon_2).
the first iterator of the 2nd input range. Its value type is Polygon_with_holes_2 (respectively General_polygon_with_holes_2).
the past-the-end iterator of the 2nd input range. Its value type is Polygon_with_holes_2 (respectively General_polygon_with_holes_2).

memberdef.name: join

briefdescription.para: Given a range of polygons (respectively general polygons) and a range of polygons with holes (respectively general polygons with holes) computes the union of all polygons in the two ranges and inserts the resulting polygons with holes (respectively general polygons with holes) into a container via an output iterator.

parameterdescription.para: determines whether the boundaries of the polygons in the input ranges are treated as cyclic sequences of single ( $x$-monotone) segments or as a cyclic sequences of ( $x$-monotone) polylines. If substituted with CGAL::Tag_true, which is the default, the input polygons are converted into general polygon with holes , bounded by polylines before the operation is actually performed. Then, the resulting general polygons with holes are converted back to standard polygons with holes. If substituted with CGAL::Tag_false, pgn1 and pgn2 are used as is. Refer to Traits Selection for more information.
the first iterator of the 1st input range. Its value type is Polygon_2 (respectively General_polygon_2).
the past-the-end iterator of the 1st input range. Its value type is Polygon_2 (respectively General_polygon_2).
the first iterator of the 2nd input range. Its value type is Polygon_with_holes_2 (respectively General_polygon_with_holes_2).
the past-the-end iterator of the 2nd input range. Its value type is Polygon_with_holes_2 (respectively General_polygon_with_holes_2).
the output iterator for the result. Its dereference type must be convertible to Polygon_with_holes_2 (respectively General_polygon_with_holes_2).

simplesect.para: the past-the-end iterator of the output container.
GpsTraits must be a model of the concept GeneralPolygonSetTraits_2.

detaileddescription.para: There are several overloaded function templates called join() that compute the union of two polygons.

parameterdescription.para: determines whether the boundaries of the input polygons are treated as cyclic sequences of single ( $x$-monotone) segments or as cyclic sequences of ( $x$-monotone) polylines. If substituted with CGAL::Tag_true, which is the default, the input polygons are converted to general polygons bounded by polylines before the operation is actually performed. Then, the resulting general polygon with holes is converted back to a standard polygon. If substituted with CGAL::Tag_false, the input polygons are used as is. Refer to Traits Selection for more information.

listitem.para: The types Type1 and Type2 of the parameters and of InputIterator1::value_type and InputIterator2::value_type must be convertible to the types specified in a row in the table below, respectively. The 3rd column specifies the corresponding dereference type of the output iterator.
The types that apply to signatures (1.1.) and (5.1.) above are restricted to those listed in rows 14 in the table below.
The types that apply to signatures (1.2.) and (5.2.) above are restricted to those listed in rows 58 in the table below.
The type of InputIterator::value_type in (3.1.) above must be convertible to either Polygon_2 or Polygon_with_holes_2.
The type of InputIterator::value_type in (3.2.) above must be convertible to either General_polygon_2 or General_polygon_with_holes_2.

parameterdescription.para: the input polygons.
a range of input polygons.
the first range of input polygons.
the second range of input polygons.
the resulting polygon.
the output iterator for the result.
an optional traits object.
